name: linux-technologic: Disable the isl12022 rtc driver from the device tree

data.description:
On the customer ts4900 daughter board there are problems with this rtc
device on the i2c bus. In lack of schematics to check if changes have
been made to the rtc in relation to the i2c bus, we will disable this
driver so that timedatectl and friends won't error out when trying to
read the rtc:
rtc-isl12022 0-006f: isl12022_read_regs: read error, ret=-6

Changelog-entry: Disable the isl12022 rtc driver for ts4900 because of unknown customer hw modifications
Signed-off-by: Florin Sarbu <florin@balena.io>

name: Recast the `actor` property in `session` cards as an `is owned by` link

data.description:
This is part 1 of a series of PRs aimed at closing #3263.

Change-type: major
Signed-off-by: Carol Schulze <carol@balena.io>

Current concerns:
- Ergonomy loss due to lack of link-aware functions in `core/kernel`
- Lack of a low-level constraint checking for links may lead to subtle bugs
- The `linked_at` field becomes extra noise that needs to be filtered in some tests

**NOTE:**
This needs to be merged before the request-password-reset pull request OR the base branch should be changed to master

Action and handler for completing the password reset

- [x] should have a prehook that hashes the submitted password
- [x] should check that the user still exists and has not been disabled
- [x] should check that the token is still valid
- [x] updates user record with new password
- [x] should invalidate the reset-password card (set it to inactive by using the remove card func)
- [x] send success to server

name: Add support for querying for multiple link types with a single JSON schema query

data.description:
Closes #3332

Change-type: minor
Signed-off-by: Carol Schulze <carol@balena.io>

***

A query for multiple link types will return cards with all link types at the same time.

name: Move device actions under the "device" folder

data.description:

Signed-off-by: Stevche Radevski <stevche@balena.io>

##### Contributor checklist

- [ ] Introduces security considerations

##### Reviewer Guidelines
- When submitting a review, please pick:
  - '*Approve*' if this change would be acceptable in the codebase (even if there are minor or cosmetic tweaks that could be improved).
  - '*Request Changes*' if this change would not be acceptable in our codebase (e.g. bugs, changes that will make development harder in future, security/performance issues, etc).
  - '*Comment*' if you don't feel you have enough information to decide either way (e.g. if you have major questions, or you don't understand the context of the change sufficiently to fully review yourself, but want to make a comment)
